Deflationary means the price goes up relative to goods. This cannot happen if you want stable Bitcoin unless the price of goods gets cheaper
I want # Bitcoin to be deflationary not stable. A good currency is stable. A good store of value is deflationary. Fiat & crypto co-exist
In summary I want # Bitcoin to be deflationary not stable. A god currency is stable. A good store of value is deflationary. You need both.
But national currencies can change supply to keep stable. Bitcoin can't which is why it's a great store of value and volatile.
Which means Bitcoin is not a deflationary currency anymore even though it has a fixed supply. It does not make sense.
But you want to eliminate fiat so everything will be priced in Bitcoin so not measure against USD.
That would mean Bitcoin would have to have a flat price and people will have to start thinking in terms of 8 decimal places. You see that?
You either save in inflationary currency or deflationary currency or you buy asset. How do you propose stabilising crypto?
So you want goods to have 700 price labels for every crypto. What would goods be priced in? How would you determine price of bread?
Almost all Altcoin's are ways for users to try to make or lose more Bitcoin.
Dash is a speculative investment so you can make more Bitcoin.
Bitcoin is a savings account that allows you to spend it however you want and covert to stable currency to pay rent.
Exactly. That's why crypto needs to be pegged to fiat. You use Dash because you want it to increase in value not be stable is my guess.
If it was not centralised it would take long as Bitcoin to make changes. A few people control & governments can knock on door to shut down.
Bitcoin will never become like PayPal. It will always be traded to stable currencies. Bitcoin is deflationary and will always be volatile.
If anybody was using it for anything other than speculation it would not have many of those properties. It's too centralised to be Bitcoin.
